channel.title: Question on columns
channel.description: Okay you know how there are columns on the side of every website with the links and such? Well go to www.neopets.com and look at their column on the left side. Is it possible to make one like that in Photoshop and then try and set the links with coordinates like Neopets did? (Look at home page source code)

item.title: Question on columns
item.dc:creator: @arraness14 arraness14
item.description:
@arraness14 wrote:

KyleGut3:

ok, so your not doing multiple html pages in one. Good.

heres how we do it:

1. Create your Navigational Column/Sidebar in Photoshop
2. Load your HTML pages with Dreamweaver And go into the "Design View"
3. Insert the Navbar where you want it [you will need to use tables, etc. to get it in the right position]
4. Make sure your properties window is up [Window > Properties]
5. Click on your Image and look down at the properties bar [You should see something called "map"]
6. Click the rectangle with a star in the top left corner
7. Draw on your hotspots
8. Click a hotspot and goto the properties bar again
9. Where it says link, link to the url of the page the hotspot coresponds to.
10. Repeat 8-9 as necessary.

EDIT:
Il'l probably make a tutorial on advanced graphic navigational bars using Dreamweaver later today/tonight]

Thanks alot dude and I hope you make that tut

Read full topic

item.title: Question on columns
item.dc:creator: @KyleGut3 KyleGut3
item.description:
@KyleGut3 wrote:

ok, so your not doing multiple html pages in one. Good.

heres how we do it:

  1. Create your Navigational Column/Sidebar in Photoshop
  2. Load your HTML pages with Dreamweaver And go into the "Design View"
  3. Insert the Navbar where you want it [you will need to use tables, etc. to get it in the right position]
  4. Make sure your properties window is up [Window > Properties]
  5. Click on your Image and look down at the properties bar [You should see something called "map"]
  6. Click the rectangle with a star in the top left corner
  7. Draw on your hotspots
  8. Click a hotspot and goto the properties bar again
  9. Where it says link, link to the url of the page the hotspot coresponds to.
  10. Repeat 8-9 as necessary.

EDIT:
Il'l probably make a tutorial on advanced graphic navigational bars using Dreamweaver later today/tonight]

item.description:
@arraness14 wrote:

KyleGut3:

One question first, Are you using tables, divs, or actual columns[using multiple HTML pages] for this column.

umm I'm not sure. I was thining of making a picture of a column in photoshop and then adding it to every page of my website and then adding the links with dreamweaver some how.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @itendsnow itendsnow
item.description:
@itendsnow wrote:

You could easily insert a table...then insert image then add hotspots or imagemap over the top of it.

item.title: Question on columns
item.dc:creator: @arraness14 arraness14
item.description:
@arraness14 wrote:

KyleGut3:

Yeah, actually its very easy to do that using Macromedia Dreamweaver. They allow you to simply draw your hotspots onto the image in your viewing screen while you make your page.

Thanks for telling me about it

Is it free?

Read full topic
